awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is concerned with the study of geometric properties of objects that can be defined algebraically. Such objects, called algebraic varieties, are very special and have a rich structure. Consequently, techniques from other fields of mathematics, such as Arithmetic, Topology, and Differential Geometry, are employed in their study. Within algebraic geometry, this project studies the geometry of moduli spaces. A moduli space is the space of all shapes of objects with prescribed numerical invariants. The study of moduli spaces is of central importance to several branches of mathematics and theoretical physics. In particular, over the past three decades there were deep cross-influences between Mathematics and Physics centered around a special class of algebraic varieties, the Calabi-Yau threefolds, and their moduli. One of the main thrusts of this project is the development of tools for the study of moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau varieties. 

In this project, the moduli spaces are studied from the perspective of period maps. The period map is an essential tool for understanding the geometry of the moduli space of  abelian varieties and K3 surfaces. Beyond these classical cases, the investigation of the period maps is much more difficult due to some non-trivial and highly transcendental conditions (the Griffiths' transversality conditions) satisfied by the Variations of Hodge Structure arising in the geometric setting. Nonetheless, recent progress in the field makes possible the investigation of  some non-classical situations, especially surfaces of general type with small invariants, and Calabi-Yau threefolds. In a different direction,  several questions about the geometry of the moduli space of K3 surfaces and hyper-Kaehler manifolds are investigated by means of period maps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The general area of the project is Algebraic Geometry. Algebraic Geometry is concerned with the study of geometric properties of objects defined by polynomial equations (such as conics, cubics, and higher degree objects). Within algebraic geometry, the focus of the project was on study of moduli spaces, i.e. how objects of similar shape fit together in families, or ``moduli''. The main technique used in this investigation is Hodge theory, a subtle and powerful tool that combines analytic, algebraic, and arithmetic ideas.

Concretely, several of the results of the funded project were concerned with the geometry and topology of hyper-Kaehler manifolds. These manifolds form a very special class of algebraic varieties, which play a key role in the classification of algebraic varieties. Roughly speaking, the hyper-Kaehler manifolds are right in the middle of this classification. Consequently, understanding the structure of hyper-Kaehler manifolds is of crucial importance. The PI and his collaborators have obtained a series of significant results in this direction, especially concerning the so classed LLV decomposition of the cohomology, and the boundedness of certain invariants of hyper-Kaehler manifolds. In a different, but related direction, the PI has obtained a number of results regarding the behavior of degenerations from a Hodge theoretic perspective. 

The research results supported by these award resulted in about 10 publications and preprints. These results were widely disseminated through talks at specialized seminars and international conferences, as well as several lecture series based on the research of the PI. The results obtained are at the core of algebraic geometry, but they are very pertinent in other fields in mathematics, and nearby fields such as mathematical physics. 

The PI is very active in mentoring and advising students and postdocs, with a good track record in advancing their career. The PI also (co-)organized multiple activities that while focused on top-level research, they also had a strong training component targeted to junior participants.
